titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Thursday.

Rising at five O’Clock, I began as usual the day with reading three chapters of the Bible, and by the version of one Stanza of the 18th. Psalm.— I then revised the two half sheets of proof from Mr Eastburn, and after an early Breakfast went with I. H. Adams to Cambridge— I found Ward N. Boylston at the door of President Quincy’s yard, and gave him the commendatory Letter that I had written for him; with directions to attend at 6 O’Clock to-morrow Morning, to pass examination for his admission: and I told him I would attend in the course of to-morrow Evening to ascertain the result of his examination.— I then attended in the President’s Study the Meeting of the Judges of the Boylston prize Declamations— There were present Mr Bowditch, Mr Ward, F. C. Gray, John Pickering, Mr Palfrey, Judge Jackson, and Mr Gould— There were two juniors ten Seniors and two graduates of the year to contend for the prizes; of the last was Edward Cruft, who I had observed had no part in the performances of yesterday— There was a printed Synopsis of the Rules for the management of this foundation, in which the Article designating the persons appointed to act as Judges, had totally omitted my name and all reference to me as one of them—though expressly appointed as one of them, by Mr Boylston, in the foundation itself— I made this remark to President Quincy who noticed it to Mr. Bowditch—and said it should be corrected.— The rules it seems were drawn up and printed, in 1826— At nine O’Clock we went in to the Meeting house—which was not full: but of the auditory four fifths were Ladies— The Declamations were all good—marked with the same merits and imperfections as the speaking of yesterday—excepting that this day there was no defect of Memory—of which there were yesterday several instances— The Selections were from Burke, Sheridan, Webster, Byron, and other, all modern Orators except True of the Senior Class, who had taken Paul’s Speech before Agrippa, and who spoke it with so general an impression of superiority; that one of the first prizes was awarded to him by the judges at the first ballot— The other first prize on a second ballot was assigned to George Frederick Simmons a Senior— The three second prizes were taken by Bennett a Senior—Harrington a junior, and Edward Cruft, the graduate of the year— It appeared that during a part of his Collegiate term he has not improved his time to the best advantage— There were several ballotings for the second prizes— I did not return to the Meeting-house to hear the announcement of the prizes, but attended the Meeting of the ΦΒ.Κ. Society, where I found them discussing the Resolution offered by Dr Bradford to restore the Rule of requisite unanimity for the election of members— Mr Everett the President was justifying himself from an imputation of unfairness, in calling the Meetings in Boston, at which the changes in the Constitution had been made— There were about 140 members present, and Dr Bradford’s Resolution was carried, by a vote of at least 100— A motion was then made and carried, for a Committee of nine to revise the Constitution again and report at the next Anniversary. A Resolution was also adopted, that hereafter no change of the Constitution or Laws should be made, but at an Anniversary Meeting. The Society then at Noon, went in procession to the Meeting house, where an Oration was delivered by James T. Austin, upon the duties of the educated Men of our Country; and a Poem upon Liberality, by the Revd. Benjamin Kent, Minister of Duxbury. The Oration was beautiful composition,
and was equally well delivered. I was very much pleased with it, but there were some passages towards the close of it, encroached upon topics of theological controversy, which many thought not suited to the occasion, and which were offensive to a portion of the auditory, and to the orthodox members of the Society itself— They were not at-all displeasing to me, and I was surprised at hearing how much dissatisfaction they had given. It is a very important attribute the how—the where and the when truths may be told to the benefit of the hearer, and to the advantage of the Speaker.— Mr Kent’s Poem was Satirical and witty— It occasioned great good humour and laughter, much at the expense of the personages figuring at Washington— The Oration was two hours in the delivery— The poem about half an hour.— I walked to the Meeting house with my Classmate Packard; but he did not return to the Chapel— After returning, the Revd. Henry Edes and the Revd. Mr. Crocker were put in nomination for election as Members—both of Providence—Mr Edes as Minister of the Congregational, and Mr Crocker of the Episcopal Church there— Edes was proposed at the request of the branch of the Society at Providence, according to a rule established by joint consent of all the Branches, he having been graduated at Cambridge. On two ballots for each of them there was a single black ball against each of them— Mr Edes was then proposed to be balloted for, at the next anniversary Meeting; and I proposed Mr Crocker for the same further trial; for which I received the thanks of Mr Wainwright of New-York.— We then proceeded to dinner in the Hall, where about ninety members attended— There were of invited Strangers John A. King, Mr Ray, Mr Legaré, and Joseph Blunt— The dinner was jovial, convivial, and festive— Everett the President punning occasionally upon names— After one song, and a half a dozen toasts I withdrew, and called at President Quincy’s where I found him with Company at dinner.— I told him I should come to-morrow evening to ascertain the success of Ward N. Boylston, upon his examination, and I promised to attend on Saturday morning at the Installation of Mr Follen, as Professor of the German language and Literature— I then visited again Dr Waterhouse, where I saw his Son, Andrew, lately returned from England. I came back to Boston at dusk of Evening, and with Charles attended a large Evening party at the Lieutt. Governor T. L. Winthrop’s— There was a Supper to which I did not stay; but about ten came back to Charles’s house again thoroughly wearied.
2. V. Friday.

Read three Chapters of the Acts— Wrote a Stanza of the version of a Psalm—and a short answer to a Letter from Stephen Bates; and revised one half sheet of proof of my Eulogy— After Breakfast I called at Mr Edward Cruft’s where I saw him, Mrs Cruft & their Sons Edward and William—but Edward did not appear to be much gratified with the decision of the judges yesterday—I then passed three hours at the Gallery of Pictures at the Athenaeum.— The fifth annual exhibition—A Portrait of Sir Walter Scott by Leslie—Allston’s Miriam—Greuze’s Portrait of Franklin—Saul and the Witch of Endor by Allston—Chief Justice Marshall by Harding—Mr West by Leslie—Governor Sullivan, and S. Dexter by Stuart—West’s Lear—King’s boy reading a Newspaper—Dugald Stuart by Sir H Raeburn—D. Webster by Stuart and also by Harding, and Patrick Lyon the Blacksmith in his shop, were the principal interesting pictures— A few very indifferent copies from celebrated Artists were there— Some maritime Landscapes by Vernet, but excepting Alston’s no historical pictures worth any thing—and his not the best— His Miriam the prophetess looks like a dutch washerwoman—not like an inspired starveling in a Wilderness— My own Portrait by Stuart and Sully
was also there— Except the interest naturally felt in the Portraits, by those to whom the Originals, many of them now deceased, were known, there was not much to attract notice in this exhibition— I met there Mr Henry Middleton and his daughter—Mrs. Carroll, daughter in Law to the old Patriarch of Maryland, Mr Brooks of Hingham and Mr Eastburn the City Printer who told me he should send me the last proof half sheet of the Eulogy tomorrow.— After leaving the Athenaeum, I called, and left a Card at Mr Webster’s— He had gone this morning for Sandwich— I then went to James H. Foster’s, and afterwards visited at the Tremont House, Mr and Mrs White of Florida, and Mr and Miss Middleton. White relates with much relish an interview recently held with the President, who manifested great alarm at an intimation he had received, that White would publish some Letters of his to Dr Bronaugh, now in the possession of George Walton. Jackson’s fear is for the spelling—and he told White that Walton was the greatest villain in the United States, except John C. Calhoun, for shewing the Letters— Middleton read me a Letter from Daniel E. Huger shewing that the nullifiers of South-Carolina are fully determined to proceed to the last extremities of civil War— He says that Langdon Cheves told him that his opinion was the Union ought to be dissolved— That the Interests of the North and South were incompatible and irreconcileable together— That South-Carolina should wait till she could combine with her a sufficient number of Southern States and then break off from the Union.— He gave me the history of Cheves, checkered with vicissitudes which account for his present desperation.— I dined at Charles’s house, with Doctor John Hopkinson and Thomas Davis, son of Isaac P.— In the Evening I went to Cambridge, where at the College I found Mr John Lane Boylston, and his Son Ward—waiting the decision upon the examination which Ward had been the whole day undergoing— After we had been there about half an hour the lads were called up, and Ward received a ticket of Admission— I then took him to the President’s house, and introduced him to Mrs Quincy—and the young Ladies— President Quincy returned soon after from the College; but he had not the bond, ready for execution— He said he would have it ready to-morrow Morning when I should come to the installation of Mr Follen.— Mr John L. Boylston promised also to be present at the time.— Returning to Boston, I stopped and paid a visit of half an hour to Mr Fuller— It was between nine and ten at Night, when I got back to Charles’s house—much heated and worn out.
3. V. Saturday.— Cambridge— Medford— Boston— Quincy.

I went to Cambridge again this Morning, and met Mr John L. Boylston, with whom I executed in President Quincy’s study the College-bond for Ward N. Boylston, which completed all the arrangements for his admission— After this I accompanied President Quincy, and Mr Follen to the College Chapel where this Gentleman was installed as Professor of the German Language and Literature for five years— There were I think not thirty persons present, but of those Coll. Thomas H. Perkins was one— The rest were chiefly Officers of the College— The President in a short Latin Address announced the appointment of Mr Follen as Professor of the German language and Literature for five years, and Mr Follen answering also in Latin
declared his acceptance of the appointment.— The President then declared him Professor of the German language and Literature, and he delivered an inaugural discourse in English, upon the character and present condition of German Literature. It was well written and well spoken with little of the foreign accent. I returned to President Quincy’s, where I met Coll. T. H. Perkins; and soon took leave and went back to Boston— There I saw for a few minutes Joseph Blunt, who proposes to leave the City on Monday for New-York— I went in a Chaise with Charles to Medford, and dined at Mr Peter C. Brooks’s—a family party, including Alexander H. Everett, and Benjamin Gorham— Just before Sunset we left Mr Brooks’s a shower then coming on and returned to Boston with a very heavy rain— At Charles’s house I found the last half sheet of the Eulogy, from Mr Eastburn— The rain held up, and I came home in the Carriage to Quincy— But on the Neck I was obliged to get out, and mount the Coach-box, by the side of my driver— I got home between eight and nine in the Evening after an absence of four racketing days. I found all well at home, and Mary Roberdeau with Mrs Adams; who went and met her at Dedham on Commencement day. She comes from Philadelphia, to pass a few weeks with her— The agitation and bustle of the last four days has affected my health, and admonished me that these are Scenes in which I ought no more to mingle; but that retirement and Study present the state most suitable to my Condition.— The busy and stirring Scenes of youth and middle age, are not adapted to the decline beyond the bounds of three Score.— The boiling of my blood, has gathered it in two boils on my chin and cheek.
4. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney from Exodus 34.6.—“The Lord, the Lord God, merciful and gracious; long suffering and abundant in goodness and truth. 7 Keeping Mercy for thousands, forgiving iniquity and transgression and sin, and that will by no means clear the guilty; visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children unto the third, and to the fourth generation.” and in the afternoon from Psalm 32.1. “Blessed is he whose transgression is forgiven, whose sin is covered. 2. Blessed is the man unto whom the Lord imputeth not iniquity, and in whose spirit there is no guile.” Both these were Discourses against the doctrines of one portion of the Universalists, who maintain a future state of existence, but none of punishment. If there were any absurdity which some theologian had not drawn from the Bible, it would be surprizing that a creed excluding all retribution hereafter should be erected upon the basis of the Gospel— Upon this point however a number of the Universalist preachers have seceded from the rest; and have published recently a declaration announcing themselves under the denomination of Universal Restorationists. After the morning service I went to my Brothers; and found him very dangerously ill. Doctors Holbrook and Woodward were there; and Dr Holbrook told me he was very apprehensive my brother would not recover. His disease is a nervous fever, with involuntary convulsive motions of the limbs, and delirium— He has been several months declining, and almost deprived of sleep except when procured by opiates. But with this new type of the complaint he was suddenly seized in the Night of last Thursday— I saw him a few minutes in his bed— He knew me, and talked much, but as if perfectly possessed of his reason, and sensible of his own Condition; except that his discourse wandered from subject to subject— He asked me to come to him again to morrow, which I promised— Mrs Cushing from Scituate came to pass
a couple of days with us. Mr Middleton, Commodore Hull, and Baron Stackelberg paid us a visit this afternoon. I sent the last proof half-sheet of the Eulogy to my Son Charles, to go to Mr Eastburn.— G. W. Beale and his eldest daughter Anne came here this Evening, and Lieutt. T. B. Adams junr— My face and eyes are much inflamed.
5. V. Monday.— Sun rose 5.35.

Louisa Smith spent the day here with Mrs Cushing— Price Greenleaf came after dinner, and examined the Apple and pear stocks which he had budded, and loosened the ligaments of some of them— He thought most of the buds had taken, and three or four them had already put out shoots— I wrote to my Son John, and also a Letter to John C. Calhoun, to be enclosed with copies of my last fourth of July Oration, and of my Eulogy.— Mr Calhoun was a member of Mr Monroe’s Administration, and during its early part pursued a course from which I anticipated that he would prove an ornament and a blessing to his Country— I have been deeply disappointed in him, and now expect nothing from him but evil— His personal relations with me have been marked on his part with selfish and cold blooded heartlessness.—Yet in his controversies of last winter, I sustained him as far as truth would warrant against the profligate falsehoods of Crawford— Since the publication of my 4th. of July Oration, he has published what he calls his views of nullification, but has not been explicit in his exposition of them— I propose by sending him my two discourses to give him an opportunity if he pleases to discuss with me the question upon which we so essentially differ. I walked towards Evening to my brother’s, and found him yet very dangerously ill—though apparently a little better than yesterday— After my return I read my fourth of July Oration to Mrs Cushing, and the Ladies.
6. V. Tuesday.— Sun rose 5.36.

Mrs Cushing left us this morning to return home to Scituate in the Stage; with a very cordial invitation to us to visit her there— This Lady who must be nearly four score years of age, is in herself a Chronicle of the olden time— Her husband William Cushing was one of the judges of the Superior Court of the Province before our Revolution. Then Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Commonwealth, until the organization of the Courts of the Union, when he was appointed a Judge of the Supreme Court of the United States which Office he held until his death in 1811. In January 1796 he had been appointed Chief Justice but declined the appointment— He was throughout life a constant friend of my father— Mrs Cushing has an inexhaustible fund of anecdotes extending nearly sixty years back but very few of them less than thirty years old— I attended the annual dinner of the Proprietors of Neponset Bridge at Squantum—and met there; and met there Messrs. Wayles, Joseph Head and his Son, Charles Loring and James H. Foster—Thomas and Daniel Greenleaf, Edward Miller and George W. Beale— Our dinner was upon Chowder, fish, and very good fruit— I returned before Sunset, and went with my wife to my brother’s— He is yet confined to his bed, and yet in great danger— He has watchers every Night— We found Mrs Baxter there, offering any services that she could render— I saw him for a few minutes; and he expressed his regret that he had been unable to attend the dinner of the Bridge proprietors this day, as he has for many successive years—
7. V. Wednesday.

My wife whom to distinguish from three other Mrs Adams’s we now call Madame, went to Boston this morning with Mary Roberdeau and Isaac Hull Adams, but they returned home to dinner. Mr John
Gray, with Mr George Eustis of New-Orleans were here on a visit— Eustis is a son of Jacob Eustis, and of a Sister of Mr Gray, whose marriage I well remember— He is lately from New Orleans, and came through Lexington, Kentucky, where he saw Mr Clay. He was in excellent health and Spirits— Eustis was charged with special compliments from his wife to mine, who met her three or four years since at one of the New-York watering places, and kindly noticed her.— Lieutenant Adams was here, and copied for me a Letter which I wrote to Mr Clay, in answer to one lately received from him, and with the Letter I enclosed a copy of my Eulogy upon Mr Monroe. I planted this Evening on the Eastern side of my Nursery a row of peach stones, four in each bed bordering upon the central alley; Also a row of Apple and Pear seeds— And I transplanted from a Quart glass Tumbler, two or three Strawberry plants from seeds of white strawberries which I had planted in June— Those in the white Earthen pot have already thrown out runners which are taking root in the bed— And I transplanted from one of the Earthen pots a Washington Shellbark, the nut of which was planted in June; after the Kean seedling Strawberries brought by Charles from Boston, were taken out of the Pot— The tree has come up, and I removed it with all the Earth in the Pot around it— I have many Shellbark Trees up; but their growth is but three or four Inches.
8. IV:30. Thursday.

Finished yesterday the version of the 18th. Psalm, and began this morning upon the 20th. having already versified the 19th. This work comes on slowly but steadily— It exemplifies to me, what I have often had occasion in life to remark— The power of perseverance. A power which like the other faculties of the mind strengthens itself by exercise— It is a virtue of the first order, and connected with the moral principle of undertaking none but honest ends, and with sagacity to select useful ones, is the certain indication of a great and good man— My own perseverance has been and is very imperfect— My purposes have been honest; so far as a mortal may bear testimony to his honesty before God— Honest, allowing for the involuntary self-deception of the heart— My judgment in selecting objects for persevering action, exceedingly defective, and that has been the great drawback to my success in life—and by success I do not mean my own individual prosperity; for that with great vicissitudes has been far beyond my deserts—but I mean the success of usefulness to my fellow Creatures— I have wasted my perseverance upon trifling objects—the result of which could have no operation on the happiness of mankind— One of the best objects of practical perseverance with which a young man should begin life, and pursue to its ends, is the keeping of a diary— This I began at twelve years of age—but I have failed of perseverance in keeping it, at least twenty times, and often for long and most important intervals— Few men however, have in this point had perseverance equal to mine; and they were assuredly useful men— But I have filled my journals with trash, and with every whimsey that passed across my mind— This has been an idle waste of time and a multiplication of books to no end and without end— I greatly doubt the usefulness of this end upon which I am now engaged; a metrical version of the Psalms— But I have ventured upon it, and persevere in it. Mr Potter, the Minister of the Episcopal Church called upon me with Mr Winslow, and Mr Sanford of Fayetteville, North-Carolina, the former of whom is a Grandson
of Mr Winslow, the Minister of the Episcopal Church here, before the Revolution. Dr Holbrook was here this afternoon to see Miss Roberdeau, who is suffering with rhumatism. My wife who is also complaining asked him to bleed her, but he dissuaded her from it— I walked with Isaac H. Adams this Evening to my brother’s— He is better, though not out of danger— I wrote to Charles J. Ingersoll, and received Letters from both my Sons— That from Charles with a Deed to be executed by me, with Nathaniel Curtis and Alicia Boylston to John Brooks ofAcres of Land in Princeton, of W. N. Boylston’s Estate, for 4200 dollars.
9. IV:15. Friday

Finished my version of the 20th. Psalm, with which I am very much dissatisfied.— I was not so with the 19th. Mr Lemuel Bracket came this morning from Mrs Wood, widow of William Wood, to complain of the dilapidated state of the fence between a lot of my land and one of hers adjoining it— I promised to call that way and see it— Mr Bracket took the acknowledgment of the Deed which I had received from Charles last Evening— I received from Mr Eastburn fifty copies of my Eulogy—one of which I made up for the mail, to send immediately to my Son John.— Another to Benjamin Vaughan of Hallowell, whose last Letter, received a few days since I answered—made up Copies of the Eulogy also to be forwarded to Mr Calhoun, Mr Clay, and others till my Stock was out— My nephew, the Lieutenant was here— I walked to my brother’s towards Evening. He was much better, but asleep, so that I did not see him.
10. V:30. Saturday.

Began the version of the 21st. Psalm. Received a Letter from Thomas L. M’Kenney at Philadelphia—with the first proof-sheet of a History of the Indians in large Folio, with a coloured Lithographic print of an Indian Chief Neamathla, Muscogee—from the collection painted by King; for the War Department— Mr M’Kenney wishes me to correct the proof Sheets of this Work, both the matter and Style. I answered a Letter received from my niece Mrs Johnson of Utica, with a pamphlet upon Language and a proposed English Dictionary by her husband Alexander B. Johnson read to a Lyceum at his residence— Mr Duncan and Mr Goddard were strangers from Kentucky—the latter from Louisville, who visited me from mere curiosity Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us; Towards Evening I walked to Mr J. Greenleaf’s and thence to my brother’s, and found him convalescent.

div.p: 11. IV:15. Sunday.

Mr Gannett of Cambridgeport preached this morning from Psalm 24.3. [“]Who shall ascend into the hill of the Lord? and who shall stand in his holy place? 4. He that hath clean hands, and a pure heart; who hath not lifted up his Soul unto vanity, nor sworn deceitfully.”— And in the afternoon from Galatians 5.7.—[“]who did hinder you, that ye should not obey the truth?” He dined with us, and told me that he was graduated in 1809. and had been a constant attendant upon my whole course of Lectures on Rhetoric and Oratory— He said he had taken at the time manuscript minutes of all my Lectures as they were delivered—and that he thought the observations which I made at the weekly declamations, had been as useful to him as the Lectures. He specially noticed the advice I had given to the Students to be attentive to distinct articulation; and as an exemplification of bad pronunciation told them I had heard the proudest work in the English Language spoken as if it was written Libety, entirely dropping the sound of the r. I had
had entirely forgotten this remark.— Mr Gannett also told me that Mr Timothy Fuller, who is one of his Parishioners had sold the place where he lives, and was about to remove— Mr Gourgas and Elizabeth C. Adams also dined with us. I walked to my brother’s after the second Service, and found him very much recovered—and sitting up—but my wife and Miss Roberdeau, are both much indisposed—and this Evening quite sick— I wrote to my Son Charles, to request Mr Eastburn to send me out 200 Copies more of my Eulogy.
12. IV. Monday— Sun rose 5.44.

My wife was confined to her bed, severely ill, and Miss Roberdeau to her chamber with rhumatism I sent Kirke to Milton for Dr Holbrook, who bled Mrs. Adams— Captain Smith was here, and shewed me plans drawn by Mr Willard, for the proposed new Episcopal Church; which I thought neat and simple. Captain Smith said that many of the Subscribers were desirous of building in Stone; but that there was doubt whether their funds would prove sufficient; and it would require the addition of 25 dollars to the subscription price for each pew— He asked if I would consent to that addition to my own Subscription—to which I agreed— Constant F. Oakman, came to ask my aid to obtain a pension for him as a revolutionary Soldier at the next Session of Congress— His papers are at Washington. General Macomb and Mr Swett were here on a visit— The General spoke freely of the late Secretary of War Eaton— The present Secretary of War, Lewis Cass, is a particular friend of his. He spoke also with great approbation of the present condition of the Military Academy at West Point; with the exception of the Professor of drawing, Gimbrede— Of him he thought it desirable to get rid. Mr Swett told me he was going to the Free-trade Convention, which is to sit in a few days at Philadelphia. That he wished to have some conversation with me upon the subject as he should be glad to be converted— I said I should be happy to converse with him on that or any other subject; whenever it might suit his convenience— I answered Coll. M’Kenney’s Letter, and returned his proof sheet revised.
13. IV:30. Tuesday— Sun rose 5.46.

Finished my version of the 21st. Psalm— Deacon Spear came to enquire if I had drawn up the agreement about the line of fence round the Cherry tree lot of Salt-marsh land between the Heirs of Jesse Fenno—I had it not ready, but promised to leave it for him at Briesler’s shop. The Deacon also recommended to me the sale of much standing wood—besides that upon the remnant of the Lawyer’s common; which he thinks not good for much— Thomas Vinson, a claimant for a Revolutionary War Pension, came from Weymouth, to demand my Services, at the next Session of Congress— His vouchers are at Washington; but he left with me a Statement of his claims and of his time of Service— Afterwards I had a visit of curiosity from a Mr Sellers of Philadelphia and his Sister. Towards Evening I walked to my brothers, and there met Mr Marston— My brother continues convalescent On my return home I found a card from W. H. Seward from New-York.— On going to my brother’s I left at Briesler’s shop the papers for Deacon Spear— Wrote Letters to my Son John enclosing the Note for 5000 dollars at the Union Bank Georgetown, renewable on the 18th. signed—to Joseph Blunt at New-York, in answer to a recent Letter from him— And to John B. Hearn at Chillicothe, Ohio, enclosing a copy of my Eulogy and of my Oration delivered at Washington, the fourth of July 1821. I have received from him one delivered the last 4th. of July at Chillicothe by a Mr. Leonard— I have no time left for visiting my garden and Nursery.
14. IV:15. Wednesday.

Began the version of the 22d. Psalm. Mr Seward called upon me this morning, and I had with him a conversation of three hours. He is a member of the Senate in the State of New-York, and a zealous Anti-Mason. He brought me a Letter of Introduction from Albert H. Tracy, also a New-York Senator and Anti-Mason.— They were coming together to Boston; but Tracy was taken sick at Norwich in Connecticut where his father resides, and Mr Seward came on thence without him. They are both members of the Anti-Masonic Convention, to meet at Baltimore the 26th. of this month, to nominate a Candidate for the Office of President of the United States; and have not made up their minds as to the person whom they will select— Mr Seward told me that Mr Henry Dana Ward of New-York, one of the most active Anti-masons in the Union, has corresponded with Mr Calhoun and with judge John M’lean to ascertain their Sentiments concerning Masonry, and whether they would accept a nomination for the Presidency from the Anti-masons— That both of them had in their answers declared themselves adverse to the Institution of Masonry—but Mr Calhoun’s answers were otherwise unsatisfactory.— Judge M’lean had answered that he would accept the nomination if made. That with regard to the principles of his Administration if elected, he referred them to those upon which the General Post-Office had been administered, when under his charge.— Seward said that Mr Ward was satisfied with the result of this correspondence though there had been some awkwardness, by the publication of part of one of judge M’lean’s Letter. Mr Ward was in favour of nominating him— That he found the Anti-masons here were desirous that I should be nominated; and that was the feeling of the Anti-masons in Rhode-Island— I asked him if he had seen Dr Phelps. He had, and had heard from him what had passed between the Anti-Masonic Committee and me.— I repeated to him that I had not the slightest desire for a nomination, nor for the Office of President of the United States itself. That I would not reject the nomination of the Convention if made, but my great concern was that they should agree upon their Candidate; and I was very apprehensive that they would not— And my special desire was that they should not for one instant adhere to me, if there was any other person upon whom they could unite—and I could probably be more useful to their cause if they should not nominate me than if they should.— He said he believed there was no danger of their disagreeing, with respect to the nomination of a Candidate— That after determining to take such a step, they would be all sufficiently impressed with the necessity of union to sustain their cause, to avoid splitting up into fragments. I lent Mr Seward a pamphlet and two newspapers which he promised to return before the end of the week.— I wrote Letters to Isaac S. Lyon of Parsippany, Morris County New-Jersey, inclosing copies of my Oration and Eulogy—and to judge Spencer at Albany. In the Evening I called for half an hour at my brother’s, and afterwards spent the Evening with a party at Mr Edward Miller’s— Neither my wife nor Miss Roberdeau being both confined to their chambers with illness. We suffer with rheumatism.
15. V. Thursday.

Rain, great part of the day. We sent John Kirk into Boston with the Carriage, and he brought out my Son Charles with his wife and infant daughter, to pass a few weeks with us— With I. H. Adams I went to an Evening party at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s— None of the Ladies of our family could go. I wrote a Letter to Harlow Hard, of Charlestown, Clark County, Indiana, and enclosed to him copies of my Oration and Eulogy, for the Websterian Library at that place. I had received a Letter from him requesting them, and also of my Lectures upon Rhetoric and Oratory, but of these I had no spare copy— The weather disappointed Mrs Daniel Greenleaf of half her company; but there was a supper of fruits and Syllabubs and Custards.
16. IV:15. Friday.

A gloomy day. Kept house until the Evening, and then walked with Charles to my brother’s— Planted a Nectarine Stone, Pavies, Peaches and Pear Cores in the Nursery. I wrote Letters to Samuel Martin, of Campbell’s Station, Tennessee; and to R. Rush— This Samuel Martin some ten years ago, was a member of the Legislature of Tennessee, and entered into a correspondence with me, upon the Presidency, and has written me from time to time ever since— Being an entire Stranger to me I distrusted him from the beginning, and have seldom answered his Letters at-all— I had some reason to suppose him a person used by Mr Felix Grundy for his purposes; whether known to him or otherwise. I received a Letter from him a few days since, in which he spoke kindly of Mr Monroe; and therefore now enclosed to him a copy of my Eulogy.
17. IV.30. Saturday.

My brothers Son the Lieutt. was here— I received a Letter from W. H. Seward, returning the Pamphlets and newspapers that I had sent him— His Letter has many remarks upon Free-Masonry.— I had also one from Edward Ingersoll in which he treats of that subject, and to which I propose to reply at leisure— He is one of the leading friends and partizans of Mr Clay at Philadelphia, and considers Masonry and Anti-Masonry only as they affect his prospects for the Election. It is apparent from his Letter that he is almost entirely unacquainted with all the transactions connected with the murder of William Morgan in the State of New-York, and with the course of the judicial proceedings to which it has given rise— The Power of the Institution is very strongly marked in the success which they have had in suppressing the knowledge of the facts— Their influence over the Newspapers is almost inconceivable— I had a Letter too from Mrs Sary Findley— I wrote a Letter to Chief Justice Marshall, in reply to that which I had received from him acknowledging the receipt of my Oration— I sent him last week a copy of the Eulogy.— I walked this Evening to my brother’s, where I found his daughter Mrs Angier. Edward Miller was also there— My wife is yet confined to her chamber, and was several days obliged to keep her bed— Miss Roberdeau still suffers much with the rheumatism— The pressure of my occupations, and my four days absence at Commencement have run my diary again a full fortnight in arrear: and the number of Letters which I find myself obliged to write, has delayed my taking up the chapter for the American Annual Register that I had engaged to write. My Correspondence is much increased during the distribution of my Oration and Eulogy.
18. IV:15. Sunday.

Heard a young Mr Edes, son of Mr Henry Edes of Providence. He preached in the Morning from John 8.34. “Jesus answered them Verily, verily, I say unto you, whosoever committeth Sin, is the Servant of Sin”—and in the afternoon, from the word, in 1. Peter 1.13. “be sober”— The Sermons were both ingenious very well written and excepting a little coldness in the manner well delivered— Pious, Moral, and benevolent— I did not know who the preacher was till after the close of the second Service when I was informed by Mr Beale— He is a young man of two or three and twenty, and is now preaching at Taunton, whence Mr Huntoon removed about two years since—and where he has just received a Call— Towards Evening Mrs Quincy junr. and Miss Anne Quincy, Miss Whitney, and her youngest brother Edmund Burke Mrs Angier Elizabeth C. Adams and the Lieutt.— And also Mr John Bailey, who informed me that he was going to-morrow or Tuesday, to attend the Anti-Mason Convention at Baltimore, to meet on the 26th. He spoke of the Nominations for President and Vice-President; and said he understood that Mr Seward inclined to the nomination of judge M’lean; though he himself thought the best course would be to adhere to the nominations of the last Election—me and R. Rush.— I repeated that my first wish was that they should all agree; and the point of most importance by far was to unite upon the person who should have the greatest number of votes in his favour. That I had no desire either for the nomination or the Office; and I wished the Convention so to understand.— This is not only true; but I am convinced it would far more conduce to my individual comfort that I should totally withdraw from all concern with public Affairs. And I could apply far more profitably my time.
19. IV.45. Monday

Joseph Hardwick was here this morning, and announced his intention to build a house for him to go into next April, and to remove from mine—he had also some Union Bank Shares for Sale, but which I declined to purchase.— Mr Peter Whitney brought a Letter from Origen Bacheller to him, making enquiries concerning my father’s Religious Opinions— Bacheller is in controversy with Robert Dale Owen, about Christianity— Owen is a Free-thinker. perhaps an Atheist— And in one of his publications, claims my father as an Infidel, just as Shepherd claims him, for a patron of Masonry— Mr Whitney said he should answer that my father was at the Time of his Death, and for many years before a member, and he had often heard from him his religious Sentiments but Mr Bacheller wished him also to make enquiry of me— I told him I had never heard my father utter a Sentiment of infidelity in my life— That he was not a believer of the Athanasian Creed, nor of any of the Doctrines usually called Calvinistic but he was a firm believer in Christianity, upon a profound examination of all its evidences— My brother was here— His two eldest Sons, Thomas B and Isaac H. went to Boston— My wife came down from her chamber— After dinner I walked with Charles to Mount Wollaston— My Trees are in bad condition— Returning home found some Black and Red Acorns on the Trees,—not quite ripe.
20. V. Tuesday.

I received Letters from Charles J. Ingersoll, Joseph Story, T. L. M’Kenney, my Son John, Gray and Bowen, E. Byrne, Mrs Cushing, Dr Joseph Kent, John Connell who is in Boston, and from Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn— The Letter from Gray and Bowen was to press for the chapter which I promised Blunt, for the American Annual Register.— I answered their Letter, informing them that I could certainly not be prepared with the chapter before the end of this month, but would endeavour to be so by that time. I began also an answer to Edward Ingersoll’s Letters: and as in his he touches upon the subject of Masonry, I have determined to give him my Sentiments upon the subject at large. I walked up this Evening to my brother’s. Deacon Spear was here this Morning.
21. IV:45. Wednesday.

Alpheus Spear was here this Morning; and wishes large repairs to be made at the solitary barn on the Mount Wollaston farm. I finished one Letter to Edward Ingersoll— Afternoon in the Nursery, where I planted a number of large peach-Stones— My brother’s Son the Lieutenant, and his daughter Elizabeth were here; and with Miss Roberdeau, had music of the Piano and singing. I finished this Morning the version of the 22d. Psalm—
22. IV.30. Thursday.

Began the version of the 23d. Psalm, one of those which I encounter with the greatest reluctance, because it has already been paraphrased in a very acceptable manner by Addison—with the exception of two very bad lines— [“]Though in the Sultry glebe I faint, or on the thirsty mountain pant.” My version will however be totally different from that of Addison. Mr Hall of Washington and G. S. Bulfinch paid me a Morning visit— I wrote a second Letter upon Masonry and Anti-Masonry to Edward Ingersoll. Lieutt. T. B. Adams dined with us; and in the Evening I walked to my brothers.
23. IV:30. Friday.

My Son Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine. I wrote a third and last Letter, upon the Masonic and Anti-Masonic controversy.— I wrote also Letters to my Son John and to Mr James Allen in answer to one that I had received from him.— After dinner I walked over the fields to the foot of Penn’s hill, and called upon Joseph Field, now the oldest man living in Quincy— He is also the last remnant of the age immediately preceding me in this neighborhood. His first wife was a maid in my mother’s family— He has now his third wife, and has had children by all three— His youngest son Harvey Field, has just built a house in which they all reside; on the spot where the old house was falling to ruin— I gave the old man a copy of my Eulogy upon James Monroe, and he told me that he had heard me deliver my fourth of July Oration, and that it brought all the old Times to his mind— His youngest daughter was at the house, on a call to see him—Mrs Lucy Billings, married to a man living at the farm on the way to Squantum— Just after I had left him and was walking homeward; there came up suddenly a very heavy shower of rain against which I was altogether unprotected— Mrs Billings, alone in a Chaise overtook me, and offered me a seat which I accepted— She drove me home and saved me a drenching.
24. V. Saturday.

Finished my version of the 23d. Psalm, with which I am extremely dissatisfied, and yet can do no better with it.— I wrote Letters to Charles J. Ingersoll at Philadelphia—and to Mr William Farmer in Maine.— My nephew the Lieutenant dined with us: and his
father and mother called here after dinner— Mrs Adams with Charles’s wife, and Miss Roberdeau went to Weymouth and visited Mrs Tufts— I planted Peach Stones, Apple, and Pear-Seeds in the Nursery.
25. V. Sunday

Heard Mr Lamson of Dedham, in the Morning from Matthew 6.34 “Take therefore no thought for the morrow: for the morrow shall take thought for the things of itself. Sufficient unto the day is the evil thereof.”—and in the afternoon from 1 Thessalonians 4.13. [“]But I would not have you to be ignorant, brethren, concerning them which are asleep, that ye sorrow not, even as others which have no hope”— These were two very good Sermons— The first, upon the evil of an over-anxious care of futurity, and the second upon the immortality of the Soul— Mr Lamson and Louisa C. Smith dined with us, and Mr T. Greenleafs two daughters and Coll. and Mrs Quincy paid us Evening visits. I answered a Letter some time since received from Mrs Barbara O’Sullivan Addicks, a Lady who was a few years since was troublesome to me; but is now very complimentary.
26. IV:30. Monday.

Rain the whole day, which prevented Charles and the Ladies from going to Boston, as they had intended. Ebenezer Adams was here— And after dinner a Mr Briggs from Kingston in the County of Plymouth called upon me, to make enquiries concerning a Soldier’s Land-warrant issued in favour of Sylvester Holmes, and now claimed as the property of his heirs. The warrant has never been located, and Mr Briggs knew not how to proceed to obtain the Land. He proposed to me to undertake the recovery of the Lands for a compensation which I declined. but told him that if the parties interested would send their vouchers to me at Washington I would do all that should be in my power to obtain justice for them without compensation. I planted in the Nursery four rows of Red Oak Acorns: and we had Music in the Evening; I am now resuming seriously the Chapter for the American Annual Register— But with these pressing occupations the Diary in spite of all that I can do runs into irretrievable arrear.
27. IV:15. Tuesday.

Another Rainy day, and Alpheus Spear was here again— Judge Henry Baldwin of the Supreme Court of the United States—President Quincy, and Mr Sewall of Montreal a Grandson of my fathers friend Jonathan Sewall paid us morning visits.— Judge Baldwin is upon an excursion of pleasure and relaxation. I asked Mr Sewall, if he could inform me whether his father was in possession of any Letters from mine to his grandfather written between 1760 and 1770. He did not know, but said he would ascertain upon his return to Montreal— My father was in frequent correspondence with Jonathan Sewall during that period, upon subjects of morals and general Law, of which I wish much to obtain copies— There are one or two of them among my fathers papers, which sharpen the appetite for the rest.— I received several Letters, among which one from Thomas L. M’Kenney which I answered—and one from my Son John— His wife has been very ill, but is convalescent. I finished my version of the 24th. Psalm—one of those which I believe it impossible successfully to translate into English verse— The Entrance of the King of Glory, with the repeated question who is this king of glory, and the answer cannot be versified—
28. IV. Wednesday.

I had made sometime since a version of the 25th. Psalm; and therefore began this morning that of the 26th. Charles went to Boston this morning, and returned to dine— Mr George Whitney was here, and told me that Dr Gray, his wife’s father had shewn him my versions of two of the Psalms which I gave him last Spring— I now read to him that of the 23d. which I finished last Saturday— He approved it much; but he is a friendly critic.— It is in my own opinion one of those which I have done the best; and which should convince me that I can do none of them well.— After dinner I walk’d to Deacon Josiah Adams’s, and with him over my grounds adjoining his, and which he rents of me I marked with him the Trees which he is to cut down, and bring to my house for fuel. chiefly decaying Oaks. We had an Evening party of the families residing in this neighbourhood. My brother’s, the Baxter’s, Beale’s, Greenleaf’s, Thomas and Daniel, Marston, Miller’s, Quincy’s, and Whitney’s—Mr Gourgas and Mr Hallett— The Ladies had Music and singing— The Baxters Millers and Quincy’s, are all going to pass the winter in Boston.
29. V. Thursday.

I am now devoted most industriously to the composition of this Chapter upon England, for the American annual Register; and it engrosses my time; so that I have little else to speak of here. My correspondence however absorbs time, and it is with difficulty that I keep up with its current— I received yesterday a long Letter from John Williams of Tennessee, which I had barely time to acknowledge, and this day, I began a Letter to Samuel L. Southard, which I could not finish.— This afternoon Mrs William Smith of Boston and her son Thomas paid us a visit— He invited us to the evening party immediately after his marriage, which is to be next Thursday to the daughter of Captain Bernard. Mary Roberdeau planted a peach-stone in my nursery, which she specially recommended to my care— I put down by the side of it a stake marked with her name— There was an Evening party at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s, which we attended, excepting my wife, who is very unwell, confined to her bed.
30. V. Friday.

I finished the version of the 26th. Psalm, very bad— Mrs Lee with her husband’s son William paid us a morning visit— They are going to pass the winter at Washington City— Alpheus Spear was here, and paid me the quarter’s Rent for Mount Wollaston farm to this day I wrote a short Letter to Samuel L. Gouverneur at New-York, informing him that I have entrusted the autographic manuscript, of the late Mr Monroe which Gouverneur had sent me, to Sidney Brooks, who is returning to New-York, and that I had forwarded a month since the manuscripts relating to the strange tale of John Rhea to Mr Gouverneur by the Mail. This afternoon I went with Isaac H. Adams to Mount Wollaston, where I found my Apple-trees planted last year, in less promising condition than the appearance of last Spring had led me to expect— Most of the Seedlings which had come up have perished in the course of the Summer— The trace even of most of the hills where the Seeds had been deposited is lost, though it may easily be recovered.— Returning home, I gathered about half a peck of Acorns—from two varieties of the black Oak, and from the red Oak— These are this year in bearing— The white Oaks are not— We attended an Evening party at Coll. Quincy’s; where we had the Music of the Piano, and singing.

Day. As the three preceding Months— After the printing of my Eulogy upon James Monroe was completed and the copies which I have distributed among my friends were sent off; the chapter for the American Annual Register occupied me, and it is not yet finished. This with my correspondence still makes the Diary run in arrear but I have nothing of importance to record.
